A sea is a large body of salt water that is surrounded in whole or in part by land. More broadly, "the sea" is the interconnected system of Earth's salty, oceanic waters—considered as one global ocean or as several principal oceanic divisions.

Seawater is water from a sea or ocean. On average, seawater in the world's oceans has a salinity of about 3.5% (35 g/l, 599 mM). This means that every kilogram (roughly one litre by volume) of seawater has approximately 35 grams (1.2 oz) of dissolved salts (predominantly sodium (Na+) and chloride (Cl−) ions).

Water is a liquid.
Water is a transparent fluid which forms the world's streams, lakes, oceans and rain, and is the major constituent of the fluids of organisms.
The water is a transparent, tasteless, odorless, and nearly colorless chemical substance that is the main constituent of Earth's streams, lakes, and oceans, and the fluids of most living organisms.

A body of water is a natural physical feature, a body of liquid on the surface of a planet.
A body of water or waterbody is any significant accumulation of water, generally on a planet's surface.
A lake is a water body of a significant size, localized in a basin, that is surrounded by land apart from a river, stream, or other form of moving water that serves to feed or drain the lake.

The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest of Earth's oceanic divisions.
A lake is an area of variable size filled with water, localized in a basin, that is surrounded by land apart from any river or other outlet that serves to feed or drain the lake.
